facts.text: Plaintiff Kundanlal and defendants 1 to 5 (Banarsi Das, Kanshi Ram, Kundan Lal, Munnalal, Devi Chand and Sheo Prasad) are brothers and formed a joint Hindu Family till 1936, owning inter alia Sheo Prasad Banarsi Das Sugar Mills at Bijnor, UP.
After family disruption in 1936, brothers decided to carry on sugar mill business as partners at will, equal shares in profits and losses.
Partnership agreement: mill managed by designated brother; Banarsi Das managing partner for 1936-37 starting Sep 1,1936; subsequent years by unanimous nomination, else previous continues.
Kundanlal was managing partner for 1941-44.
Sheo Prasad (defendant No.5) instituted suit for dissolution of partnership and accounts on May 13,1944 in Subordinate Judge, Lahore against Kundanlal, joining others as defendants.
Court appointed Mr. P.C. Mahajan as Receiver on Aug 3,1944; parties dissatisfied, revised to High Court where they settled; High Court appointed Kanshi Ram as Receiver from Apr 5,1945.
District Magistrate Bijnor took over mill under Defence of India Rules; appointed Kundanlal and son as agents for U.P. Government for 1944-45, renewed for 1945-46.

Parties except Devi Chand applied on Aug 28,1946 to Lahore Court for Receiver to execute 5-year lease in favour of Banarsidas at District Magistrate's suggestion; Subordinate Judge ordered accordingly.
Banarsidas obtained possession of mill in Sep 1946.

Sheo Prasad applied for distribution of Rs.8,10,000 out of Rs.8,30,000 with Receiver, suggesting withhold for Kundanlal and Banarsidas; amount distributed to all brothers; Devi Chand acknowledged receipt Nov 14,1946.
Lahore suit dismissed for default on Oct 11,1947 post-partition migration.
Sheo Prasad instituted suit Nov 8,1947 in Civil Judge Bijnor for injunction restraining Banarsidas from acting as Receiver; dismissed Mar 3,1948.
Sheo Prasad transferred his 1/6th share to Banarsidas on Jul 16,1948; Banarsidas receiving profits for both since.
Kundanlal instituted suit Oct 7,1948 against brothers for: declaration partnership dissolved May 13,1944 (or dissolve if not); accounts from def 1&2; pendente lite Receiver; other reliefs.
Banarsidas filed written statement Jul 30,1949; others did not appear.
Application for Receiver dismissed Dec 18,1950 as Kanshi Ram continued as Receiver from Lahore High Court.
During suit pendency, Banarsidas entered agreement with Devi Chand and Kanshi Ram to take over their rights for 5 years from Jul 1,1951.
Banarsidas applied Feb 19,1951 for Kanshi Ram to lease mill to him for 5 years from Jul 1,1951 (prior lease expiring Jun 30,1951).
Mr. Mathur appointed Receiver Apr 26,1951; granted 5-year lease to Kundanlal from Jul 1,1951 on terms to be settled.
Issues framed Dec 7,1951 including whether 1946 lease to Banarsidas void ab initio/voidable.

Apr 2,1954: Kundanlal's advocate withdrew issue on lease; only accounts left; trial court decreed: dissolved May 13,1944; shares 1/6th each (Banarsidas 1/3rd? wait text: plaintiff 1/6th, def1 1/3rd? error? text: plaintiffs share 1/6th of def No.1 Seth Banarsi Das as 1/3rd and defs 2-4 1/6th each; Kanshi Ram accounts for stores; Mathur continue receiver; Kashi Nath Commissioner for winding up, prepare accounts, then sale.
Three appeals to Allahabad High Court: by Kanshi Ram, Banarsidas, Munnalal (ex-parte against them); winding up not challenged.

High Court Mar 15,1956: dismissed Banarsidas/Munnalal appeals, partially allowed Kanshi Ram: declared dissolved May13,1944 shares as trial court, but dismissed other reliefs on limitation Art.106; used O.41 r.33 CPC.
Banarsidas preferred CAs 94-96/1960; Kundanlal CA 97/1960 by certificate under Art.133(1)(c).

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit was barred by limitation under Art.106 Limitation Act, particularly for accounts and distribution of assets of dissolved partnership.
Date of dissolution of partnership at will: whether upon filing suit for dissolution on May 13,1944, or later.
Whether High Court could raise limitation plea first time in appeal without issue/remittal, despite s.3 Limitation Act.
Whether High Court could use O.41 r.33 CPC to disallow trial court's decreed relief.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under Partnership Act, partners entitled to wind up business even if suit for accounts barred by Art.106 Limitation Act.
Kanshi Ram as court-appointed Receiver in fiduciary relation, bound to render accounts independently.
Limitation not raised in plaint or appeal grounds; mixed question of fact/law, High Court should have framed issue and remitted under O.41 r.25 CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Limitation Act s.3; CPC O.41 r.25

petitioner_arguments.text: Limitation did not commence May 13,1944; mere suit filing not dissolution notice under s.43 Partnership Act; requires date in notice or communication; summons service date needed, unknown.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Partnership Act s.43; CPC O.20 r.15

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court wrong to invoke O.41 r.33 CPC.

respondent_arguments.text: Partnership at will dissolved from suit institution date May 13,1944 analogous to partition suit.
Suit for accounts and asset distribution barred by Art.106 Limitation Act; plaint discloses bar, court duty under s.3 to dismiss.

court_reasoning.text: Admission of dissolution on May 13,1944 binds only on facts, not law; partnership at will not dissolved merely by suit filing, as no notice under s.43(1) with date; plaint not 'notice'; even if, dissolution from summons service on last defendant, date unknown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Filing suit for dissolution does not ipso facto dissolve partnership at will without decree or proper notice.

court_reasoning.text: Limitation plea mixed fact/law; not raised below; High Court erred allowing first time without opportunity to amend pleadings, frame issue, remit; caused prejudice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.3 Limitation Act does not justify surprise plea without procedure.

court_reasoning.text: High Court overlooked possible acknowledgments or other bars to limitation.
Not fit case for new point by non-contesting defendants.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plea by defendants without written statements.

holdings.text: Suit not barred by limitation; High Court erred in procedure and finding.
Partnership at will dissolved not automatically on suit filing; requires notice per s.43 or decree per CPC O.20 r.15.
High Court should have followed O.41 r.25 if allowing new plea.

precedents_cited.relevance: Mere suit for dissolution not notice of dissolution.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Dissolution of at-will partnership by notice with date; suit plaint not notice.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Suit for accounts barred after 3 years; court must dismiss if barred even if not pleaded, but procedure needed for new plea.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Dissolution date in decree for partnership suits; remit issues; appellate power to vary decree; no appeal from consent decree.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeals of Banarsidas (CAs 94-96) and Kundanlal (CA 97), set aside High Court judgment, restored trial court decree declaring partnership dissolved from May 13,1944, shares as fixed, accounts from Kanshi Ram, receiver and commissioner to continue for winding up and sale.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of trial court decree for dissolution declaration, accounts, winding up.

key_quotes.text: "The mere fact that a party goes to court asking for dissolution does not operate as notice of dissolution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies no automatic dissolution on suit filing for at-will partnership.

key_quotes.text: "Where the partnership is at will, the firm may be dissolved by any partner giving notice in writing to all the other partners of his intention to dissolve the firm."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.43(1) Partnership Act to distinguish plaint from notice.

key_quotes.text: "It is quite possible that had an opportunity been given to the defendants, they could have established... that the suit was not barred by time because of acknowledgment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Highlights prejudice from surprise limitation plea.
